DOC.HEAD: Boston Launches Huge Shopping Center in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: In what was billed as the largest American investment in Northern Ireland, Mayor Raymond Flynn announced the development of a $100 million shopping center in the economically troubled city of Londonderry. ``We're all keenly aware of the trouble in Northern Ireland,'' Flynn said at a news conference Thursday with British and Irish officials and Cardinal Bernard Law. ``But today, what is happening in America is very special. We're reaching out and bringing a new kind of hope, one that transcends words. It brings jobs and economic opportunity.'' Groundbreaking will begin next fall on the 300,000-square-foot complex, which should provide about 1,400 jobs in office, service and construction, Flynn said. The shopping center, funded by a Quincy-based developer, is expected to open in 1992. The project stems from Boston Ireland Ventures, a non-profit group founded in 1987 by Flynn and Northern Irish political leader John Hume to spur economic growth in the north and west of Ireland. Hume leads the Social Democratic and Labor Party, representing moderate Catholics in Northern Ireland. Londonderry, also known as Derry, the second largest city in Northern Ireland, is in one of the poorest areas in the country, with unemployment rates of up to 45 percent. After 18 months of negotiations with the British government, which rules Northern Ireland, O'Connell Development Co. agreed to build the complex. The company's other projects include waterfront complexes such as the World Trade Center and Bayside Exposition Center in Boston and the Marina Bay complex in Quincy. ``This is the essence of cooperation,'' said Liam Canniffe, consulate general of Ireland. ``They are welcoming you on the streets of Derry. There are great ties between America and Ireland and now there are great ties between Derry and America.''
